awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  The Rules of Predation: Linking Biomechanics and Ecology in the Bat-Insect Arms Race
awd_abstract_narration:
How a predator pursues its prey may be one of the most important aspects of its behavior. Predation success determines survival for nearly all animals, be they predator or potential prey. We know little, however, about the specific movement abilities of predators and prey in nature and how they determine the outcomes of life-or-death encounters. It is difficult to study natural predation; these events are rare and difficult to anticipate. Predators use a variety of movement strategies to hunt prey: striking with great speed, sneaking up stealthily, and maneuvering quickly and repeatedly during pursuit, to name a few. This research will address how bats hunt insects using different predation strategies, dissecting the physiology and anatomy that underlie the abilities of particular species to select their form of pursuit. This research will provide rich learning opportunities for teams of students in biology, engineering and computer science. It will develop a science communication internship program at Brown University where students will transform research videos of bats hunting insects into media that will be distributed globally and that highlight the importance of bats and insects to our ecosystems.

This project uses the model system of bats and insects to link detailed understanding of the mechanistic basis of locomotion with experiments and simulations that examine how movement abilities influence predator-prey interactions. Bats and insects are highly diverse groups that have co-evolved for millions of years. The researchers will use emerging video-recording and computer vision technologies to quantify with high precision the movement abilities of several bat species as they hunt insects under natural conditions. These field studies will be complemented by studies of bats flying in a custom flight arena that allow measurement of bat flight movements in greater detail. Flight and predator-prey computer simulations will be used to test hypotheses regarding what determines bat flight abilities and how movement abilities affect predator-prey outcomes. This will lead to open-access computer software that will help scientists studying a variety of animals to predict flight abilities and the outcomes of predator-prey interactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to deepen our understanding of predator-prey interactions using bats and insects as a model system. Specifically, we sought to uncover the rules governing aerial predation in diverse environments and to investigate how the structure and mechanics of bats' wings affect their pursuit flight performance. Over the course of the project, we achieved significant progress in both of these areas, blending field studies, lab-based experiments, and simulations to build a comprehensive picture of bat flight dynamics.

Key Findings and Intellectual Merit
One of the most exciting outcomes of our research was the development of a cutting-edge method for tracking 3D flight movements in bats using deep-learning tools. This approach allows us to capture highly detailed flight data without requiring physical markers, improving our ability to study natural behaviors in wild bats. Using this method, we analyzed flight patterns from multiple species of bats and gathered the largest dataset on bat turning maneuvers to date.

Our analysis showed that bats employ a variety of pursuit strategies, combining stealth and rapid movements to catch their prey. For example, Townsend’s big-eared bat uses a multi-phase pursuit strategy that integrates both direct and predictive navigation techniques. This finding has not only expanded our understanding of bat behavior but has also opened new avenues for studying flight mechanics across other animal species.

In addition, we explored how different aspects of wing structure, such as muscle arrangement and tendon size, contribute to the bats' agility and efficiency during flight. Our work demonstrated that bats lose heat through their wings during flight, particularly in the forearm and wrist muscles, and that this heat loss can influence their performance. These results are critical for understanding how animals manage energy and temperature during intense physical activities.

Broader Impacts
Our project had several educational and public outreach components aimed at increasing public awareness and understanding of bats and their ecological roles. We developed educational materials, including a coloring book about bat ecology, which has been distributed in local schools and translated into multiple languages. We also designed a science outreach website that provides teachers and students with interactive content on bat flight and biomechanics.

Our team has been actively engaged in outreach through social media, school visits, and public presentations. We collaborated with National Geographic and other media outlets to share our research, and our bat-tracking software is now used by wildlife professionals across the U.S. and internationally. By fostering collaborations with schools and contributing to public events, we have helped spark curiosity about bat biology and the importance of biodiversity.

Conclusion
This project has significantly advanced our knowledge of how bats hunt and navigate their environments, contributing to the broader field of biomechanics and animal behavior. The educational tools and public engagement efforts developed through this work will continue to inform and inspire future generations of scientists and conservationists.
